annotation.TEXT: <- Surprise spikes that /totally/ didn't kill me and several others the first time playing this stage. Nope, not at all. >_>

These Battle Toads-esque orange snakes are actually pretty neat, and could have easily served as a new main gimmick for Snake Man's stage. It's a shame that this is the only instance of them in the entire game, though (apparently they see more use in co-op mode, but as far as single player mode goes, it's a one and done experience).

And to top all of this off, the closest checkpoint is back at the start of the second elevator section. So I hope you enjoy doing that bit over and over again, because I sincerely doubt that anyone is going to beat the last stretch of this stage on their very first try. Just to further add salt into the wounds though, the alternate path to get the letter in this stage (which is found at the very first elevator section) is even more difficult, partly due to a shielded enemy placed at the very end while you're riding a magnet.

With that being said, it's time to finally show that glitch in action. Something tells me the charged shot was never factored in with quick weapon switching (seeing as it's an unlockable and all). If you charge your buster, quick-switch to Time Slow, then activate it, EVERY SINGLE one of your shots becomes an auto-charged shot.

This raft, while a neat idea, suffers from the same problem as the orange snakes. It gets used for a little while in this stage, and then it's never seen again (for all I know this could be a different story in co-op, but as I mentioned in the comments, I don't really have anyone else to help test that out).

And now for the main reason I went to Snake first: You can kill the mini-boss instantly with his weapon (and you get an achievement for it as well). If you actually fight it normally, it produces force beams from its sides and starts rotating them around the room. It's not terribly difficult, but I can see it easily catching new players off-guard when it starts to spin (at least, I know it happened to me the first time).

Alright, I've been putting this off for long enough...Tornado Man's stage is, at least in my view, the worst of the eight main levels. This is mainly due to the usage of those Dr. Mario pills (and yeah, I know they're most likely supposed to be magnets, but I can't help it with the comparison). I've never liked these things to begin with, and their obnoxious potential is brought out in full force here (especially in the final stretch).

The only thing worth noting on with Snake Man himself is his jumping pattern. Generally, he seems to leap to the center when he gets close to the edges on the left or right. Other times however, he drops straight down to the floor. It seems completely random as to which one he'll do, and it makes dodging him a bit more of a pain than it normally would.

First instance of yoku blocks, and they're directly over an instant death pit (come to think of it, I don't think there's any spots in this game where yoku blocks appear over a regular floor or an area that won't kill you if you fall down).

As for Quick Boomerang: It functions pretty much the same as it did in MM2, with the exception that it no longer pierces through things that it destroys (which sadly does hurt its usefulness a bit. This is especially noticeable if you try use it on the Pipi's in Tornado Man's stage...but we'll get to that soon enough).

Even though Quick Man is weak to Time Slow, it's still preferable to use it here to bypass the final set of lasers. You'll still have enough left over to use on him if you want to abuse a particularly fun glitch. If not, you'll basically be dealing with Doc Quick's AI patterns (Quick Man seems to jump and shoot randomly, as opposed the actual pattern he had in MM2 - which was just marred by the fact that he kept running into walls).

The ninja cloud is the least of this level's concerns, though it's still a dick move (even with the spinning enemy that tries to hint at it). Weirdly enough, this and the cloud in Snake Man's stage (which was way better telegraphed) are the only instances of foreground objects actively getting in the way of platforming. Not that I'm complaining, though. I can see that sort of thing getting annoying real fast.

Wasting no time jumping back into things, it's time to go after Snake Man. Normally Quick Man would be next in the weakness chain, but Snake's weapon is so useful in that stage that I can't really pass it up (plus, it allows me to delay visiting my least favorite stage in the game for a bit longer).

Yes, Pipi's can actually bypass the Star Crash depending on how they move (and they're also rigged to never drop any items). Aside from them, this last section is just...I'll be blunt: the magnets and rain do not mix. It's enough to edge a section like this from "challenging," to "unbelievably irritating." You're mainly at the mercy of the magnet's timing, just waiting for it to spin you to the right position (and if you so much as make a single, minor error, you're pretty much dead).
